Let {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{X_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}} be a diagram in \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}} such that \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {X_\bullet }\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {C} has a universal cocone {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}}. By assumption, {TUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{Tc_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone. We may define a further cocone TUX_\bullet \xrightarrow {\alpha _{X_\bullet }}UX_\bullet \xrightarrow {c_\bullet }{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}. The universal property of Tc_\bullet then gives us a unique morphism {TC}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{C} satisfying the following condition:

That c_\bullet lifts to a cocone of algebras is exactly the defining condition of \alpha _{\bar {C}}=\beta via the universal property of {TUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{Tc_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TC\right \}\mathclose {}}}; uniqueness of the algebra structure with this property follows from the same universal property.

In this section, we gather some useful definitions and results concerning creation of (co)limits. The reason for stating these things explicitly is that the usual definitions of created (co)limits are deeply irrational in a variety of incompatible ways, so it is important to fix definitions that can work from the start. It would be good to reformulate this in terms of displayed categories of algebras.

Let {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {D}} be a functor and let \mathcal {I} be a category. The functor U is said to create (co)limits of \mathcal {I}-figures when for any diagram {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{C_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}} such that \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {C_\bullet }\mathcal {C}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {D} has a (co)limit, then C_\bullet has a (co)limit that is both preserved and reflected by U.
We aim to understand sufficient conditions for a forgetful functor to create colimits. As we will show below, it is sufficient for these colimits to be preserved the the monad.

fr:title.text: Reflection of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reflection of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category and let \mathbb {T} = {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on \mathcal {C}, writing {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} for the forgetful functor from the Eilenbergâ€“Moore category \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}. If T preserves colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures for a given indexing category \mathcal {I}, then {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} reflects colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures.

Let {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{X_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}} be a diagram in \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}} and let {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{y_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Y\right \}\mathclose {}}} be a cocone in \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}} such that {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{Uy_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{UY\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone for UX_\bullet = \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {X_\bullet }\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {C}. We must show that {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{y_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Y\right \}\mathclose {}}} is a universal cocone.

In particular, we must factor any cocone {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{z_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Z\right \}\mathclose {}}} uniquely through {X_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{y_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{Y\right \}\mathclose {}}}. Because Uy_\bullet is universal, there exists a unique {Y}\xrightarrow {{h}}{Z} such that the following diagram commutes:
We must check that h is a homomorphism of \mathbb {T}-algebras:

through the cocone {TUX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{TUy_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{TUY\right \}\mathclose {}}}, which is universal by our assumption that T preserves \mathcal {I}-colimits.

html:li.html:p: First we must check that the following diagram commutes:

html:li.html:p: This holds immediately from the homomorphism property of y_\bullet .
Second, we must check that the following diagram commutes:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw = TUX_\bullet , sw = UX_\bullet , se = {\mathopen {}\left \{UZ\right \}\mathclose {}}, ne = {\mathopen {}\left \{TUY\right \}\mathclose {}}, north = TUy_\bullet , west = \alpha _{X_\bullet }, south = Uz_\bullet , east = Th;\alpha _Z, width = 2.5cm, }

html:li.html:p: This follows from the factorization Uy_\bullet ;h=Uz_\bullet and the homomorphism property of z_\bullet .

fr:title.text: Creation of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Creation of colimits by the forgetful functor

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category and let \mathbb {T} = {\mathopen {}\left (T,\eta ,\mu \right )\mathclose {}} be a monad on \mathcal {C}, writing {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} for the forgetful functor from the Eilenbergâ€“Moore category \mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}. If T preserves colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures for a given small category \mathcal {I}, then {\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}}\xrightarrow {{U}}{\mathcal {C}} creates colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures.

Let {\mathcal {I}}\xrightarrow {{X_\bullet }}{\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}} be a diagram such that \mathcal {I}\xrightarrow {X_\bullet }\mathcal {C}^{\mathbb {T}}\xrightarrow {U}\mathcal {C} has a (co)limit cocone {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}}. Let \bar {C}={\mathopen {}\left (C,\alpha _{\bar {C}}\right )\mathclose {}} be the canonical algebra structure on the colimit apex C such that {UX_\bullet }\xrightarrow {{c_\bullet }}{{\mathopen {}\left \{C\right \}\mathclose {}}} lifts to a cocone of algebras. Then we conclude that this cocone is universal because U reflects colimits of \mathcal {I}-figures. It is evident (by definition) that U preserves this colimit.
